technical-data.invention-title: VORRICHTUNG ZUR ERHITZUNG UND ZUFUHR VON HEISSEM UND/ODER KOCHENDEM LEITUNGSWASSER UND TANK FÜR EINE SOLCHE VORRICHTUNG
APPARATUS FOR HEATING AND SUPPLYING HOT AND/OR BOILING TAP WATER AND A TANK FOR SUCH AN APPARATUS
APPAREIL PERMETTANT DE CHAUFFER ET DE FOURNIR DE L'EAU DU ROBINET CHAUDE ET/OU BOUILLANTE ET RÉSERVOIR DESTINÉ AUDIT APPAREIL

abstract.p: Apparatus for heating and supplying hot and/or boiling tap water of at least 80 °C, comprising a main water supply connector (2) for connecting the apparatus to a main water pipe, and furthermore a water storage and heating tank, which tank has a bottom and a top, in which the tank has an inlet which is connected to the main water supply connector, in which the inlet is provided on the bottom part of the tank, in which the tank furthermore has an outlet which is provided on the top part of the tank, which outlet can be connected to a tap, and in which an electrical water heating element (3) is fitted in the water tank, above the inlet. The invention is characterized by the fact that the inner surface of the water storage and heating tank is made of or coated with titanium.

Apparatus for heating and supplying hot and/or boiling tap water of at least 80 °C, comprising a main water supply connector (2) for connecting the apparatus to a main water pipe, and furthermore a water storage and heating tank, which tank has a bottom and a top, in which the tank has an inlet which is connected to the main water supply connector, in which the inlet is provided on the bottom part of the tank, in which the tank furthermore has an outlet which is provided on the top part of the tank, which outlet can be connected to a tap, and in which an electrical water heating element (3) is fitted in the water tank, above the inlet. The invention is characterized by the fact that the inner surface of the water storage and heating tank is made of or coated with titanium.

La présente invention a trait à un appareil permettant de chauffer et de fournir de l'eau du robinet chaude et/ou bouillante à au moins 80 °C, lequel appareil comprend un connecteur d'alimentation en eau principal (2) permettant de connecter l'appareil à une conduite d'eau principale. La présente invention a en outre trait à un réservoir de stockage et de chauffage d'eau, lequel réservoir est doté d'un fond et d'une partie supérieure, et est équipé d'une entrée qui est connectée au connecteur d'alimentation en eau principal. L'entrée est prévue sur la partie de fond du réservoir, lequel réservoir est en outre équipé d'une sortie qui est prévue sur la partie supérieure du réservoir, laquelle sortie peut être connectée à un robinet, et un élément de chauffage d'eau électrique (3) est disposé dans le réservoir d'eau, au-dessus de l'entrée. L'invention est caractérisée par le fait que la surface intérieure du réservoir de stockage et de chauffage d'eau est constituée de titane ou est revêtue de titane.

La présente invention a trait à un appareil permettant de chauffer et de fournir de l'eau du robinet chaude et/ou bouillante à au moins 80 °C, lequel appareil comprend un connecteur d'alimentation en eau principal (2) permettant de connecter l'appareil à une conduite d'eau principale. La présente invention a en outre trait à un réservoir de stockage et de chauffage d'eau, lequel réservoir est doté d'un fond et d'une partie supérieure, et est équipé d'une entrée qui est connectée au connecteur d'alimentation en eau principal. L'entrée est prévue sur la partie de fond du réservoir, lequel réservoir est en outre équipé d'une sortie qui est prévue sur la partie supérieure du réservoir, laquelle sortie peut être connectée à un robinet, et un élément de chauffage d'eau électrique (3) est disposé dans le réservoir d'eau, au-dessus de l'entrée. L'invention est caractérisée par le fait que la surface intérieure du réservoir de stockage et de chauffage d'eau est constituée de titane ou est revêtue de titane.

description.p: Apparatus for heating and supplying hot and/or boiling tap water and a tank for such an apparatus

The invention relates to an apparatus for heating and supplying hot and/or boiling tap water of at least 80°C, comprising a main water pipe connector for connecting the apparatus to a main water pipe, and a water storage and heating tank, which tank has a bottom and a top, in which the tank has an inlet which is connected to the main water supply connector, in which the inlet is provided on the bottom part of the tank, in which the tank furthermore has an outlet which is provided on the top part of the tank, which outlet can be connected to a tap, and in which an electrical water heating element (3) is fitted in the water tank, above the inlet. Domestic boilers are known, which are constructed in such a manner that the water contained therein can never reach the temperature of the atmospheric boiling point, in particular by using a thermostat which ensures that a water temperature of more than, for example, 80°C is not exceeded and the boiling point of said water is certainly not reached. The water in these boilers is under normal water pipe pressure - possibly slightly lowered by the entry block - and the boiler and the discharge lines connected thereto are completely filled with water, so that the water flows out at the same pressure.

For various domestic applications, for example for making small amounts of coffee or tea or for preparing small amounts of food, but also in laboratories, etc., it is desirable to have small amounts of hot to boiling water (temperature over approx. 80°C) directly at ones disposal.

So-called instantaneous water heaters are known which are not pressurized, that is to say in which the pressure of the water to be heated is the atmospheric pressure and in which the water is only brought to the temperature of the atmospheric boiling point (100°C) when it is drawn off. Other water heaters are known in which the water in a tank is usually kept at superatmospheric pressure and the respective thermostat is set to a value which is higher than the boiling point of water at atmospheric pressure. Where the text below mentions hot water, this is intended to mean drinking water at a temperature above approx. 80°C. In particular, but not exclusively, this is meant to refer to water of approximately 100°C, in particular a little above 100°C, stored at superatmospheric pressure in a boiler tank (or boiler vessel). Mutatis mutandis, wherever the text below mentions hot drinking water boiler(s) (also shortened to HDWB or HDWB's), this refers in
particular to so-called "boiling drinking water boilers", however expressly without excluding hot drinking water boilers for temperatures below boiling point (from approx. 80°C).

Inter alia because of the fact that tap water usually contains chlorine and/or chlorine compounds, hot water, in particular water of more than approx. 80°C behaves in a relatively aggressive way and causes corrosion problems - certainly over time - even when for example stainless steel is used.

Usually, a non-corroding type of (stainless) steel, for example alloyed with CrNi, is used as material for the boiler vessel of HDWB's. In practice, it has been found that, the combination of the (corrosive) properties of hot water and the material stresses resulting from the treatment of the stainless-steel starting material during the manufacturing process - such as deep-drawing of (part of) the stainless-steel boiler vessel, welding or soldering of the various stainless-steel parts - may cause (severe) corrosion in the case of long-term use of HDWBs. Measures such as manufacture or assembly under clean-room conditions, special surface treatments of stainless-steel surfaces coming into contact with the hot water have been found to be ineffective. All this may result in warranty claims, compensation payments and a negative image of HDWB's in general. It is an object of the present invention to offer a solution to these problems and to provide an HDWB which has a very long service life and can be used in a wide range of applications without any form of corrosion.
In order to meet these and other requirements and desires, the invention provides an apparatus for heating and supplying hot and/or boiling tap water of at least 80°C, comprising:
• a main water supply connector (2) for connecting the apparatus to a main water pipe,

• a water storage and heating tank, which tank has a bottom and a top, in which the tank has an inlet which is connected to the main water supply connector, in which the inlet is provided on the bottom part of the tank, in which the tank furthermore has an outlet which is provided on the top part of the tank, which outlet can be connected to a tap, and in which an electrical water heating element (3) is fitted in the water tank, above the inlet,

in which the inner surface of the water storage and heating tank is made of or coated with titanium.
In an embodiment, the material is a metal or alloy. Preferably, 80% or more of the material consists of an element from the titanium group.

The titanium group (lUPAC group number 4) from the periodic table of elements comprises the elements with two electrons in both the outer s subshell and in the outer d subshell. These metals are highly resistant to corrosion and are used in the industry for applications which require materials which are lightweight and strong at the same time. The elements in this titanium group are titanium (Ti, atomic number 22), zirconium (Zr, 40), hafnium (Hf, 72) and rutherfordium (Rf, 104). In particular, consideration may be given to titanium as said element from the titanium group. In particular with a view to the ductility, a material is preferably chosen from a group consisting of titanium grade 1 , titanium grade 2, titanium grade 3, titanium grade 4, titanium grade 7, titanium grade 11 and titanium grade 12.

Preferably, titanium grade 2 is chosen, in particular for those parts or surfaces of the device, such as (part of) the boiler tank which are manufactured by deep-drawing and/or another cold-deforming process. The advantage of a pure type such as titanium grade 2 is that very few, if any material stresses occur during deep-drawing etc. Likewise, no appreciable material stresses occur when fitting or welding, for example, pipe bushings through the tank. By thus minimizing the material stresses, the risk of stress corrosion - one of the major causes of the corrosion problems associated with the use of stainless steel (which is, after all, relatively difficult to deform due to its relatively high alloy content) is minimized. For other parts, a less pure titanium grade may even be chosen or, for example for fittings, inlet tubes, etc. - a titanium alloy may be chosen which can, for example, be readily cut (during manufacture).

Since the corrosion problem occurs in particular in the boiler tank, including welding and/or soldering seams, pipe bushings, etc., the invention thus preferably provides that parts and/or surfaces of the tank which come or can come into contact with the heated water and/or are or may be otherwise affected by the heated water, are made of or coated with said material. Preferably, the tank is at least substantially made of said material, for example titanium grade 2. If the tank is composed of, for example, an inner tank and a surrounding outer vessel, with the intermediate volume being, for example, evacuated in order thus to achieve good heat insulation, it would suffice to only make the inner tank - which is after all the (part of the) tank which is actually in contact with the hot water and/or is otherwise affected thereby - from titanium, and to make the outer tank and/or other parts which are not in contact with the hot
water and/or otherwise affected thereby from a different material which is, for example, less expensive or more suitable for another reason. The actual boiler tank can also be insulated by providing, for example, an (independent) jacket made of insulating material or an

(independent) double-walled evacuated insulation casing around the boiler tank, in which case the heat insulation is achieved in the generally known manner (such as for example thermos flasks, double-glazed windows, etc.) due to the fact that there is a vacuum between the two walls of said double-walled insulation casing. The insulation casing does not have to be in direct contact with the boiler tank and therefore does not have to form part of said actual boiler tank.

Instead of making the respective parts (entirely) - the tank and/or the fittings, bushings, etc. - it is also possible to coat surfaces of these parts, at least those surfaces which come into contact with the hot water and/or are otherwise affected by (the heat and/or the vapour of) the hot water (by coating, cladding etc.) with a (thin) layer of titanium or of another material from the titanium group. Such a coating only has to have a thickness of a few microns.

The invention will be explained in more detail below by means of an exemplary embodiment and with reference to a figure, in which: Fig. 1 shows an exemplary embodiment of a boiler tank of a device for supplying hot water.

Fig. 2 shows an alternative exemplary embodiment of a boiler tank of a device for supplying hot water. Figs. 1 and 2 show alternative exemplary embodiments of a device for supplying hot water, in which essentially the tank 1 itself and some parts which are connected thereto can be seen. Similar parts are denoted by the same reference numerals.

Insofar as relevant, reference is also made to the publication of an earlier patent application in the name of the Applicant, inter alia published as WO2010147471 , in which a device similar to the present one is disclosed and explained in detail. The tank 1 thereof is made from a type of (stainless) steel. Insofar as relevant, the publication of this application is considered to form part of the present description of the exemplary embodiment illustrated in Fig. 1.
The tank 1 is designed to contain an amount of water, for example 2 to 20 or more specifically 3 to 10 litres. The device for supplying hot drinking water of at least 80°C illustrated here furthermore comprises a (cold) water supply 2 (including a deflection cap 2a), a (hot) water discharge 3, and a heating element 4. Preferably, the heating element has an electric power which is such that it is suitable to heat the water in the tank to the desired operating temperature, for example approx. 105°C at an operating pressure of approx. 8 to 10 bar. This pressure is caused, for example, by the pressure on the water mains and a pressure increase resulting from the water being heated in the - normally closed - tank from a supply temperature of approx. 7°C to an operating temperature of approx. 105°C. It should be noted that, at this pressure of approx. 8 bar, the water does not boil at 105°C. However, when it is drawn off, the pressure at the draw-off point will decrease to approx. 1 bar and thus it will be possible to draw off water of approx. 100°C, in other words water at a temperature around the boiling point (at 1 bar), which is suitable for example for preparing a cup of tea or coffee, or soup.

In the exemplary embodiment from Fig. 1 , the actual tank 1 is composed of three parts, i.e. an upper cover 5 produced by deep-drawing, a cylinder 7 which is produced by rolling a rectangular piece of sheet material and welding the ends thereof together - resulting in a weld seam 6 - and a bottom cover 8 which is again produced by deep-drawing. The upper cover 5 and lower cover 8 are respectively welded to the top and bottom edge of the cylinder 7, thus producing weld seams 9 and 10. The weld seams 6, 9 and 10 are formed by adding, during the welding, a small amount of welding material which substantially has the same composition as the parts which are to be welded together, in this case substantially formed by an element from the titanium group.

In the exemplary embodiment from Fig. 2, a lid-like element, here flange plate 12, is provided on top of the upper cover 5, for example made of rolled sheet material, and attached thereto by a weld seam. In order to conduct the water supply 2, the water discharge 3 and the connections of the heating element 4 through a wall of the tank 1 , that is to say through the upper cover 5 and the lower cover 8, respectively, these covers 5, 8 and 12 are provided with "bushings", that is to say punched-out holes 11 which are punched in such a manner that a circumferential weld collar is formed in each case around the punched-out hole - having a diameter which corresponds to the diameter of the respective parts 2, 3 and 4, respectively, to be conducted
through - in the punching direction, i.e. more or less transversely to the cover wall, which circumferential weld collar is attached to the surrounding material of the respective cover 5 or 8, respectively, by means of a circumferential radius. The parts 2, 3 and 4 are then inserted in the respective passage openings and welded to the weld collar from the outside on all sides by "root fusion". Due to the materials of the parts 2, 3 and 4 preferably being at least substantially identical to one another, namely all substantially consisting of the same element from the titanium group, and, in addition, also due to the effect of the shape of the weld collars which form an integral part with the surrounding (sheet) material via a radius, very few, if any material stresses occur.

All parts or surfaces of the device which come or may come into contact with the heated water or are or may be otherwise affected by the heated water, are made of or coated with a material which essentially contains an element from the titanium group. Thus, all parts shown in Figs. 1 and 2, at least the parts/surfaces which are situated on the inside of the tank 1 and can thus come into contact with the hot water, are made of or coated with a material which essentially contains an element from the titanium group.

Although titanium is a relatively expensive material, its properties - high resistance to corrosion and high ductility - make it ideally suited for the present application as it is thus possible to prevent malfunctions, compensation payments, warranty issues, etc. caused by corrosion problems, and it therefore seems very sensible to make both the tank 1 and the parts 3, 4 connected thereto completely from titanium.

Alternatively, it is possible to make some parts from another material, in which case, however, the surfaces which can come into contact with the hot water (or the heat and/or the vapour thereof) are coated with titanium or another suitable element from the titanium group.

Thus, a device for supplying hot water of at least 80°C is provided which has a very long expected service life, without having to take (expensive) measures during production and or without being confronted with after-sales costs due to corrosion problems.

claims.claim-statement: C L A I M S

claim.claim-text: 1. Apparatus for heating and supplying hot and/or boiling tap water of at least 80°C, comprising:
- a main water supply connector (2) for connecting the apparatus to a main water pipe,

- a water storage and heating tank, which tank has a bottom and a top, in which the tank has an inlet which is connected to the main water supply connector, in which the inlet is provided on the bottom part of the tank, in which the tank furthermore has an outlet which is provided on the top part of the tank, which outlet can be connected to a tap, and in which an electrical water heating element (3) is fitted in the water tank, above the inlet,
the inner surface of the water storage and heating tank is made of or coated with titanium.
2. Apparatus according to claim 1 , in which the material is a metal or alloy.
3. Apparatus according to claim 2, in which the material is a metal or alloy which consists of titanium for 80% or more.

4. Apparatus according to one of the preceding claims, in which said material is chosen from a group consisting of titanium grade 1 , titanium grade 2, titanium grade 3, titanium grade 4, titanium grade 7, titanium grade 1 1 and titanium grade 12.
5. Apparatus according to claim 5, in which said material is titanium grade 2.
6. Tank (1 ) for an apparatus according to one of the preceding claims.
